title: D.C. United earns uneventful draw against Red Bulls, keeping home playoff game within reach
text:
D.C. United goalkeeper Bill Hamid made two saves and earned a fourth consecutive shutout. (Steve Luciano/AP)

HARRISON, N.J. — Amid the unsightliness of a 0-0 draw with the New York Red Bulls on Sunday, D.C. United took a step toward hosting an MLS playoff game by remaining ahead of both its arch-rivals and Toronto FC for fourth place in the Eastern Conference with one weekend left in the regular season.

“I am past pretty right now,” United Coach Ben Olsen said. “We had a job to do, and that was to put ourselves in a position next week for a home [playoff] game, and we did that."

United (13-10-10, 49 points) registered its fourth consecutive shutout and ended a five-game losing streak to the Red Bulls (14-13-6, 48). Toronto (12-10-11, 47) settled for a 2-2 draw at Chicago, putting United in position to finish fourth by defeating league-worst Cincinnati (6-22-5) next Sunday at Audi Field.

However, captain Wayne Rooney will miss the final regular season home appearance of his MLS career before returning to England this winter. He received a yellow card in the 77th minute, pushing him past the season limit and resulting in a one-game suspension.

If United fails to host a playoff game, the striker will have played his final home match last week against Seattle.

“I am gutted,” he said. “I think [the referee’s decision] was a little bit soft.”

United has not won at Red Bull Arena since the 2012 playoffs, but given the late-season circumstances, this result was almost as satisfying as a victory. Since 2015, the Red Bulls are 10-1-5 in the series.

“We wanted to bring home a win — that would have solidified it more — but looking at the results, we have everything in our hands,” defender Russell Canouse said.

Neither team performed well: The first half was a clunker, and the Red Bulls were far more dangerous in the second. United’s Bill Hamid made an extraordinary save after intermission to help extend his scoreless streak to 414 minutes and earn a 13th shutout.

“This is probably the scrappiest match I’ve seen all year long,” Hamid said. “The foul count was high, physical all over the pitch, in the air. This was a dogfight. Maybe they will be happy with the point, but I know we are.”

United felt good about its chances, if not to win than to claim a draw and stay ahead of New York in the playoff race.

Olsen did not make any lineup changes, fully invested in a unit that took hold a few weeks ago and provides the work rate and defensive commitment that he requires.

Rooney credited, in particular, Hamid and center backs Frederic Brillant and Steve Birnbaum for thwarting the Red Bulls.

“The attacking players get a lot of credit for scoring goals and creating chances, but they got us that point,” Rooney said. “The two of them and Bill were outstanding.”

The first half was choppy and uneventful, with neither side manufacturing opportunities or testing the high-end goalkeepers, Hamid and New York’s Luis Robles. With United playing more conservatively than at home last week, Rooney’s set pieces were United’s greatest threats.

Buoyed by the shutout string, United defended with confidence and was not fazed by New York’s counterattacking forays.

The half ended without any excitement, 45 minutes all but wasted. The highlight was counting the upper-deck sections at Red Bull Arena covered by tarps. (It’s at least 20.)

A sequence early in the second half epitomized the dismal state of the match. New York’s Josh Sims was presented with a golden opportunity just inside the penalty area. He shanked the shot so far off target, a teammate was able to retrieve it at the end line and cross the ball back into the mix.

Glancing at the stats sheet after the match, Olsen said, “Can you even count possession [percentages] in a game like that?”

The momentum turned in the Red Bulls’ favor early in the second half.

Brillant made a goal-line clearance by nodding aside a close-range header. Two minutes later, Hamid made a breathtaking stop, springing to his right to get his fingers on Cristian Casseres Jr.'s bid from inside the penalty area.

United was going nowhere in the attack. Meanwhile, the collective defensive effort alleviated pressure, not unlike recent harrowing victories at Montreal and Portland.

“We didn’t break,” Olsen said. “Overall, a good point.”

Notes: Forward Ola Kamara, whom Olsen said Friday would return to active duty after a two-game absence, did not travel because of a lingering hamstring injury. …

For the third consecutive year, New York won the Atlantic Cup, awarded to the winner of the season series. The Red Bulls won at Audi Field, 2-1, last month.
